EIddleko,ou Oct 31st, 1897.
Medical Society.

Return Of Captain. Parry.-On Wednesday
morning Captain Parry, and his surgeon, DIR. Bev-
ery, arrived at the Caladonian Hotel here, after
another arduous but unsuccessful attempt to accom-
psh the Polar voyage. Captain Parry came to In
verness by the Chichester Revenue Cutter, comman-
ded by Capt John Stewart. having fortunately fall
len in with Capt s. in the Orknes, on being driven
in there the 22d ult. The history of the present
enterprise is brief; and while we have to commune
cate the agreeable of the safe return of Capt
Parry to his country and friends, able, at the
same time to vouch for the accuracy of the follow
ling particulars. Capt. Parry, on leaving the Dis
covery Ship at the appointed place. off the Spitz-
bergen coast betook himself to the sledge boats pre-
pared for his conveyance over the ice in pursuance
Iof his original Intentions and Instructions and was
out for the space Of sxtyone days. of the boats
being underhis charge, and the other under that
of Lieut.. Ross. These two boats were hauled over
the ice by the crew of the ship, twelve men to each;
and after undergoing incredible fatigue, they felt
that for great part Of the time, they float
ing icebergs which carried them southwark, while
they were stretching every nerve to proceed north
ward; and thus, of necessity, they were compelled
portant fact in the clearest point of view, we have
to mention that during the last three days ofthe exp
dtion, and on taking his observations by the chron-
ometer, Capt Parry found that his boats had gained
two miles only. The expedition arrived at latitude
82 45 and had il proceeded but fifteen miles fur
ther. Capt. Parry and his men would have obtained
the pecuniary remuneration to which they enti-
titled reaching 49,; but even this short distance
was found unattainable by any physical effort Near
ly in the same line we proceeded, to the Hecla. I'm
mediately on reaching the ship the expedition then
proceeded homeward. We are happy to add, that
Capt. Parry his officers and men, are in good health.



There is now in Paris female named Elizabeth
Thomas Cordieux, native of Savoy, who was born
on the 9th December, 17l4 !; and who is, in all pro-
liability, the French say, the Doyenne (the senior)
uf the human race. Her face is not more wripkled
than that Of female half her age, her sight is good,
her appetite excellent and she can walk ten miles
day without exhaustion she does not make use Of
stick to support herself and it really true that she
has trudged all the way, on foot, from her native
mountains to the metropolis of France. She pas
sed through Lyons and Dion, where she attended
her liberal compensation for the benefit they obtain
ed from her presence, people coming from all parts
to behold the senior Of the hannan race. The aged
dame has been already presented to the Dauphin,
Dauphiness, and the young Duke Bordeaux. She
is to go the round of the theatres for her benefit
and that Of the managers, who expect to reap great
profit from exhibiting her to the public.


CoNsTANTINorLE. Aug. 81.
From to 1900 men, infantry and artillery, left
this capital, last week, for the Dardanees, where
great preparations for defence are making Per-
feet tranquility, however, prevails here and we'll in


formed persons are generally Of opinion there will
be no rupture.


ANooNA, Sept. IL.
A Greek schooner which had several times touch
ed at our port, and had always been received with


the greatest hospitality, has seized, near Ithaca,
pontifcal trabocolo commanded by John Samson,
whom it robbed of 400 crowns and his rigging 1t


is thus it has returned the hospitality it received in
the states Of the pope.
(Fom the huerness Cour;er.) }

THE Justices of the Peace n the several counties
Of thisState hereby requested to make their re-
turns ofthe fines, imposed by them, also the names
of the Constables, who had the collection Of sald
fines


Those Justices Of the Peace, who have neglected
to make their returns for several years past,
quested to make return OF all the fines imposed by
them since their last return


Attention to this notice is requested, as a report
will be made to the Legislature of all those who neg
lect to make their report according to Law.


Also the Road Commissioners of the County of
New Castle who have not made their returns of the
expenditures on Roads and Bridges, in their respec
tive hundred for the year of 1896, are requested to
forward them as soon convenient
S. WILLIAMS,

Gen. Jackson is now in his 68th or 69th year--and
Of course, if he succeeds will be about TO- when he
takes the chair. How wonderful that nobody has
ever before found out his fitness for the Presden-
cy!
From the ~. Fl. Journal.

Nappears from the Alexandria Gazette Of yesterday tha,
there are the Senate of Ohio, "a friends of the Admins.
trato out Of 56 members and in the House OF Repre-.
sentatives our strength still greater while in Congress
we have eleven three i'll the House, and both Senators,
OHIO.

The Lynchburg Virginia, Of the 25th ultimo.
lsays, 4" We have received second communication
from Mr.. Madison. from which we learn that, in
disappearing of the proceedings of the General As.
sembiy of the State, which would limit the power
of Congress- over trade, regulations having revenue
alone for their obect,' he designed to give it as his
|opinion that Congress has Alright to impose tariff
of duties having for its objects protection and en-
coa4, ageme,,t of domestic manufacturers" This was
the doctrine Of MIR. Madison and ninetenths OF the
Congress, in 1889, and nobody could doubt that it
was his doctrine still. But, after the argument
against it, inferred from the opinions of MIR. M. on
other topics, it is well that he has suffered his
opinion upon it to be given to the world in explicit
terms.


Mr.. Madson's Letter has spread dismay in the
Opposition ranks. The great lever. the uncon-
stitutionaity of the Tariff, that theme of so much
defamation, and of so much legislative hoeu'
pocus. has broken in their hands. Mr.. Madison
thinks that the power to protect Manufactures II
not only constitutional, but was primary conside
ration in adopting the Constitution The wire draw
ers and hair spltters, what has become OF their in
tangible theories and learned deductions9 their con
structiun construed, constitu tions vndcated, ant
contemporaneous expostions Swept away by the
first touch Of the BROOM k'chmona Vig.

Iuisu puuC sthiluinS h1OU u tO Oc FHe we call up
on Mr.. Tazewel to satisfy the people Of the truth
OF a statement, which even at this late day, has
made the blood Of the public run cold. Did not
Gen. Jackson 20 to the Senate chamber to chastise
John w. Eppes, for animadverting his public con-
duct? Was he not restrained alone, by the remon-
strances, and declaration of the Godlike Decatur,
that he should pass over his dead body, to the per-
petration Of his intended outrage? Has not Mr.


Tazewell heard Decatur recount the circumstances,
and has he not himself often recounted them, with
the language and feelings which daring an outrage
ought to inspire?


! The statements made by ..NEsroR" in the Demo-
cratic Press, and repubished in this Gazette last
week. relative to scene between Decatur and Jack
son. before the door of the Senate Chamber, are
pronounced BY writer in the Richmond Wing to
| be s.true beyond doubt" The writer seems a.
ware, however, that unless NEsroR's account be
proved by evidence which cannot be disputed, ma
ny will effect to disbeieve it,; he therefore cal Is up
on LrrrLEroN WALLER TAzwELL and JOHN TYLER,
the present Virginia Senator's for their evidence in
the case These gentlemen were intimate with
Commodore Decatur, have heard him relate the cir
cumsances, and have it fully in their power TO dsa
buse the reputation of General Jackson, it, in any
Essential particular injustice has been done to it.
Should these distinguished men remain silent in
matter SO imperiously demanding their interference
will at least be as good evidence against the Hero
las any that he has yet produced in support of his
charges against Mr.. Clay .4ler. Gazette.


From the Richmond Whig.


O>.4nother Refutation on!-What charge made
BY the partizans Of Gen. Jackson that has not been
refuted What evidence relied on by them to estab-
lish charge. but has turned out against them What
statement affirmed by them, but has proved upon
investigation, absolutely unfounded, or grossly exag
gerated Another instance Of this reckless menda
city has Just been made public Lying, is reduced
by the Jackson operatives, to perfect system. No
sooner is one told and exposed in quarter of the
Union, than it is succeeded by another in some other
quarter. Their circulation since March, 1925, has
been rapid, unintermtted and tremendous.


Another SANDER is nailed to the counter. Ano-
ther witness cited to prove the bargain, gives ev-
dence of its falsehood, and would call the blush to
the cheek of those who had asserted it, had they not
passed the point of blushing. The :. Western Til
ler," an Ohio paper, stated that Col. Bourne, Re-
cever of the Land Office at Chcothe, declared he
had received letter from Member Of Congress,
shortly before the election, which contained the
'bargain'' in so many words; ma mely: Mr..
Adams has agreed, if placed IN The Presidency by
Nh. C9ay's friends, to make him (Mr. c. Secretary
Of State" To make the statement more impress
sive, it was announced that Col. Bourne son-n-
law of General Macarthur, warm friend Of Mr..
Clay, and who as Representative Of Ohio, voted
for Mr.. Adams. The Inference left for the public
to draw, that General Macarthur had written the
letter, and that coming from quarter so high and
confidential, as to Mr.. Clay, it must be entitled to
implicit confidence. The following from Colonel


Bourne to the Editor Of the Scioto Gazette, puts
down the whole story. Thus has another attempt
at proving the 6 bargain'' failed


/ "When have occasionally engaged in political
discussions the conversation has generally turned


on the principles and practice Of governments. ra-


ther than party politics As I have never been a


party man, in the strict sense of the word. and be-
ing under particular obligations to any party,
. have sometimes freely expressed my opinion o


what believe to be the errors of all parties and


this one of the topics of the conversation which
gave rise to the present controversy


As to the last Presidential election, never did be


lieve, and never said that believed, that there was
lany bargain, purchase, sale or corrupt intrigue be
. tween the friends of Mr.. Clay and the friends 0
Mr.. Adams, and never did, in my own mind, at


ach the least degree Of crimnality to their conduc
in that election. This was distinctly stated in tn
n aforementioned conversation.


n If have ever said, that received, by lette
d from member Of Congress, direct proof OF an un
e derstanding, or agreement between the friends Q
Mr. Clay and the friends Of Mr.. Adams, respectin
: the Presidential election, then have nadvertent
stated that which is not true for have never re
at ceived any such proof" A BOURNE
1t October 13, 1927.

One of the most violent declaimers against the
woollens bill, in South Carolina, is represented as
buying bale of Domestic Woollens, taking coun-
Gil of his purse instead Of his preudices, and finding
it advisable, in the present case, not to agree with
those of his countrymen who 'propose never to
buy any articles from the manufacturing states.'
As the story now goes. the body that was suppos-
ed to be Morgans proves to be that Of a man from
Canada, and Mr.. Ellting who had been almost Nor
ganzed turns out to be an impostor.
The committees from Hartford and Cecil Coun-
ties appointed to select and recommend a suita-
bic person to be supported as an Elector Of Pres-
dent and Vice President, met at Port Deposit, Oct.
97 agreeabiy to public notice; and COL JAMES
SEWALL, of Cecil County, was unanimously re-
commended to the support of the citizens Of those
counties. Gen. Thomas NJ. Forman has also been
nominated in the same Electoral District. Col.
Sewall is friendly to the Administration, and Gen.
Forman to Gen. Jackson.


The people of this country have been compliment
ed on their character, conduct, and intelligence :
but many of the statements IN the Opposition prints,
if they are published to be believed, seem to imply
that the people are ignorant; wanting usual discern
ment easily led astray by any tale told by inte-
rested persons; mt knowing the difference between
the interests Of aspiring politicians and those of the
nation afflicted with the most hurtful prejudices /;
more influenced by their passions than by fact, ar
gument, and probability and if not destitute of
common sense, having just brains enough to be i'm
posed upon by the numerous fabrcations Of the OPP
position.

vast and useful body Of information subject not

ton and the real interest of the great the

considered

quested, as business of general interest will come be-
fore them. CUTHBERT s. GREEN, Sec'y.


EIddleko,ou Oct 31st, 1897.

full articles.headline: (Fom the huerness Cour;er.) }
full articles.article:
Return Of Captain. Parry.-On Wednesday
morning Captain Parry, and his surgeon, DIR. Bev-
ery, arrived at the Caladonian Hotel here, after
another arduous but unsuccessful attempt to accom-
psh the Polar voyage. Captain Parry came to In
verness by the Chichester Revenue Cutter, comman-
ded by Capt John Stewart. having fortunately fall
len in with Capt s. in the Orknes, on being driven
in there the 22d ult. The history of the present
enterprise is brief; and while we have to commune
cate the agreeable of the safe return of Capt
Parry to his country and friends, able, at the
same time to vouch for the accuracy of the follow
ling particulars. Capt. Parry, on leaving the Dis
covery Ship at the appointed place. off the Spitz-
bergen coast betook himself to the sledge boats pre-
pared for his conveyance over the ice in pursuance
Iof his original Intentions and Instructions and was
out for the space Of sxtyone days. of the boats
being underhis charge, and the other under that
of Lieut.. Ross. These two boats were hauled over
the ice by the crew of the ship, twelve men to each;
and after undergoing incredible fatigue, they felt
that for great part Of the time, they float
ing icebergs which carried them southwark, while
they were stretching every nerve to proceed north
ward; and thus, of necessity, they were compelled
portant fact in the clearest point of view, we have
to mention that during the last three days ofthe exp
dtion, and on taking his observations by the chron-
ometer, Capt Parry found that his boats had gained
two miles only. The expedition arrived at latitude
82 45 and had il proceeded but fifteen miles fur
ther. Capt. Parry and his men would have obtained
the pecuniary remuneration to which they enti-
titled reaching 49,; but even this short distance
was found unattainable by any physical effort Near
ly in the same line we proceeded, to the Hecla. I'm
mediately on reaching the ship the expedition then
proceeded homeward. We are happy to add, that
Capt. Parry his officers and men, are in good health.



There is now in Paris female named Elizabeth
Thomas Cordieux, native of Savoy, who was born
on the 9th December, 17l4 !; and who is, in all pro-
liability, the French say, the Doyenne (the senior)
uf the human race. Her face is not more wripkled
than that Of female half her age, her sight is good,
her appetite excellent and she can walk ten miles
day without exhaustion she does not make use Of
stick to support herself and it really true that she
has trudged all the way, on foot, from her native
mountains to the metropolis of France. She pas
sed through Lyons and Dion, where she attended
her liberal compensation for the benefit they obtain
ed from her presence, people coming from all parts
to behold the senior Of the hannan race. The aged
dame has been already presented to the Dauphin,
Dauphiness, and the young Duke Bordeaux. She
is to go the round of the theatres for her benefit
and that Of the managers, who expect to reap great
profit from exhibiting her to the public.


CoNsTANTINorLE. Aug. 81.
From to 1900 men, infantry and artillery, left
this capital, last week, for the Dardanees, where
great preparations for defence are making Per-
feet tranquility, however, prevails here and we'll in


formed persons are generally Of opinion there will
be no rupture.


ANooNA, Sept. IL.
A Greek schooner which had several times touch
ed at our port, and had always been received with


the greatest hospitality, has seized, near Ithaca,
pontifcal trabocolo commanded by John Samson,
whom it robbed of 400 crowns and his rigging 1t


is thus it has returned the hospitality it received in
the states Of the pope.

Notice

TO JUSTICES OF THE PEACE.
full articles.article:
THE Justices of the Peace n the several counties
Of thisState hereby requested to make their re-
turns ofthe fines, imposed by them, also the names
of the Constables, who had the collection Of sald
fines


Those Justices Of the Peace, who have neglected
to make their returns for several years past,
quested to make return OF all the fines imposed by
them since their last return


Attention to this notice is requested, as a report
will be made to the Legislature of all those who neg
lect to make their report according to Law.


Also the Road Commissioners of the County of
New Castle who have not made their returns of the
expenditures on Roads and Bridges, in their respec
tive hundred for the year of 1896, are requested to
forward them as soon convenient
S. WILLIAMS,


.auaitor Of .accouats STATE Of Delaucdre.

full articles.headline: From the ~. Fl. Journal.
full articles.article:
Gen. Jackson is now in his 68th or 69th year--and
Of course, if he succeeds will be about TO- when he
takes the chair. How wonderful that nobody has
ever before found out his fitness for the Presden-
cy!

full articles.headline: OHIO.
full articles.article:
Nappears from the Alexandria Gazette Of yesterday tha,
there are the Senate of Ohio, "a friends of the Admins.
trato out Of 56 members and in the House OF Repre-.
sentatives our strength still greater while in Congress
we have eleven three i'll the House, and both Senators,

The Lynchburg Virginia, Of the 25th ultimo.
lsays, 4" We have received second communication
from Mr.. Madison. from which we learn that, in
disappearing of the proceedings of the General As.
sembiy of the State, which would limit the power
of Congress- over trade, regulations having revenue
alone for their obect,' he designed to give it as his
|opinion that Congress has Alright to impose tariff
of duties having for its objects protection and en-
coa4, ageme,,t of domestic manufacturers" This was
the doctrine Of MIR. Madison and ninetenths OF the
Congress, in 1889, and nobody could doubt that it
was his doctrine still. But, after the argument
against it, inferred from the opinions of MIR. M. on
other topics, it is well that he has suffered his
opinion upon it to be given to the world in explicit
terms.


Mr.. Madson's Letter has spread dismay in the
Opposition ranks. The great lever. the uncon-
stitutionaity of the Tariff, that theme of so much
defamation, and of so much legislative hoeu'
pocus. has broken in their hands. Mr.. Madison
thinks that the power to protect Manufactures II
not only constitutional, but was primary conside
ration in adopting the Constitution The wire draw
ers and hair spltters, what has become OF their in
tangible theories and learned deductions9 their con
structiun construed, constitu tions vndcated, ant
contemporaneous expostions Swept away by the
first touch Of the BROOM k'chmona Vig.

Gath October, 1897.
A board for the examination of Mdshipmen,
whose warrants bear date prior to the 1st January,
1919, has been ordered to assemble at the Navy,
Yard, Brooklyn, N. Y. on Wednesday the 7th No
vember next Commodore CHAuNcEy will be pre-
sdent.


After that examination is closed, another will be
ordered for certain Midshipmen whose dates o.
Warrant are subsequent to ist january, 1919.

Iuisu puuC sthiluinS h1OU u tO Oc FHe we call up
on Mr.. Tazewel to satisfy the people Of the truth
OF a statement, which even at this late day, has
made the blood Of the public run cold. Did not
Gen. Jackson 20 to the Senate chamber to chastise
John w. Eppes, for animadverting his public con-
duct? Was he not restrained alone, by the remon-
strances, and declaration of the Godlike Decatur,
that he should pass over his dead body, to the per-
petration Of his intended outrage? Has not Mr.


Tazewell heard Decatur recount the circumstances,
and has he not himself often recounted them, with
the language and feelings which daring an outrage
ought to inspire?


! The statements made by ..NEsroR" in the Demo-
cratic Press, and repubished in this Gazette last
week. relative to scene between Decatur and Jack
son. before the door of the Senate Chamber, are
pronounced BY writer in the Richmond Wing to
| be s.true beyond doubt" The writer seems a.
ware, however, that unless NEsroR's account be
proved by evidence which cannot be disputed, ma
ny will effect to disbeieve it,; he therefore cal Is up
on LrrrLEroN WALLER TAzwELL and JOHN TYLER,
the present Virginia Senator's for their evidence in
the case These gentlemen were intimate with
Commodore Decatur, have heard him relate the cir
cumsances, and have it fully in their power TO dsa
buse the reputation of General Jackson, it, in any
Essential particular injustice has been done to it.
Should these distinguished men remain silent in
matter SO imperiously demanding their interference
will at least be as good evidence against the Hero
las any that he has yet produced in support of his
charges against Mr.. Clay .4ler. Gazette.


From the Richmond Whig.


O>.4nother Refutation on!-What charge made
BY the partizans Of Gen. Jackson that has not been
refuted What evidence relied on by them to estab-
lish charge. but has turned out against them What
statement affirmed by them, but has proved upon
investigation, absolutely unfounded, or grossly exag
gerated Another instance Of this reckless menda
city has Just been made public Lying, is reduced
by the Jackson operatives, to perfect system. No
sooner is one told and exposed in quarter of the
Union, than it is succeeded by another in some other
quarter. Their circulation since March, 1925, has
been rapid, unintermtted and tremendous.


Another SANDER is nailed to the counter. Ano-
ther witness cited to prove the bargain, gives ev-
dence of its falsehood, and would call the blush to
the cheek of those who had asserted it, had they not
passed the point of blushing. The :. Western Til
ler," an Ohio paper, stated that Col. Bourne, Re-
cever of the Land Office at Chcothe, declared he
had received letter from Member Of Congress,
shortly before the election, which contained the
'bargain'' in so many words; ma mely: Mr..
Adams has agreed, if placed IN The Presidency by
Nh. C9ay's friends, to make him (Mr. c. Secretary
Of State" To make the statement more impress
sive, it was announced that Col. Bourne son-n-
law of General Macarthur, warm friend Of Mr..
Clay, and who as Representative Of Ohio, voted
for Mr.. Adams. The Inference left for the public
to draw, that General Macarthur had written the
letter, and that coming from quarter so high and
confidential, as to Mr.. Clay, it must be entitled to
implicit confidence. The following from Colonel


Bourne to the Editor Of the Scioto Gazette, puts
down the whole story. Thus has another attempt
at proving the 6 bargain'' failed


/ "When have occasionally engaged in political
discussions the conversation has generally turned


on the principles and practice Of governments. ra-


ther than party politics As I have never been a


party man, in the strict sense of the word. and be-
ing under particular obligations to any party,
. have sometimes freely expressed my opinion o


what believe to be the errors of all parties and


this one of the topics of the conversation which
gave rise to the present controversy


As to the last Presidential election, never did be


lieve, and never said that believed, that there was
lany bargain, purchase, sale or corrupt intrigue be
. tween the friends of Mr.. Clay and the friends 0
Mr.. Adams, and never did, in my own mind, at


ach the least degree Of crimnality to their conduc
in that election. This was distinctly stated in tn
n aforementioned conversation.


n If have ever said, that received, by lette
d from member Of Congress, direct proof OF an un
e derstanding, or agreement between the friends Q
Mr. Clay and the friends Of Mr.. Adams, respectin
: the Presidential election, then have nadvertent
stated that which is not true for have never re
at ceived any such proof" A BOURNE
1t October 13, 1927.

Thought it might not be advisable to adhere to this
rule of reporting only the substance speeches, the
next day after they delivered, in all cases still
we should suppose that the effect would be salutary
in exhibiting many members according as they ought
TO be estimated, and not by the number ofwords which
they could string together in their closets and have
inserted in public print actually delivered
in Congress.


The proceedings of the Senate will be reported


in the Journal more fully than they have been here
loiore, in that paper.


One of the most violent declaimers against the
woollens bill, in South Carolina, is represented as
buying bale of Domestic Woollens, taking coun-
Gil of his purse instead Of his preudices, and finding
it advisable, in the present case, not to agree with
those of his countrymen who 'propose never to
buy any articles from the manufacturing states.'
As the story now goes. the body that was suppos-
ed to be Morgans proves to be that Of a man from
Canada, and Mr.. Ellting who had been almost Nor
ganzed turns out to be an impostor.
The committees from Hartford and Cecil Coun-
ties appointed to select and recommend a suita-
bic person to be supported as an Elector Of Pres-
dent and Vice President, met at Port Deposit, Oct.
97 agreeabiy to public notice; and COL JAMES
SEWALL, of Cecil County, was unanimously re-
commended to the support of the citizens Of those
counties. Gen. Thomas NJ. Forman has also been
nominated in the same Electoral District. Col.
Sewall is friendly to the Administration, and Gen.
Forman to Gen. Jackson.


The people of this country have been compliment
ed on their character, conduct, and intelligence :
but many of the statements IN the Opposition prints,
if they are published to be believed, seem to imply
that the people are ignorant; wanting usual discern
ment easily led astray by any tale told by inte-
rested persons; mt knowing the difference between
the interests Of aspiring politicians and those of the
nation afflicted with the most hurtful prejudices /;
more influenced by their passions than by fact, ar
gument, and probability and if not destitute of
common sense, having just brains enough to be i'm
posed upon by the numerous fabrcations Of the OPP
position.


We have received "the proceedings of the General
Convention. at Harrisburg. OF the Agriculturaists and
and others friendly to the encouragement
and support ofthe Domestic ndusy of the United States
accompanied wtha Memorial to Congress- and Address
to the public and Appendix to this address containing


vast and useful body Of information subject not
generally fully understood but which claims the atten


ton and the real interest of the great the
people of this country.


To those who want information, simply on this subject
IS well as to those who Interested Agriculture Com
merce, Manufactures, we recommend not only perusa
but releae, study of the contents of this important pam
phet 1t can be had for re, and ought be general,
circulated, aud carefully and deliberately examined ant
considered

between Decatur and Jackson, in the lobby of the
